notes:
[2025-12-30 06:15:22]
Starting research on US recession in 2025 market. Key details:
- Current price: 0.4% Yes, 99.6% No (market heavily betting against recession)
- High volume: $11M+ 
- Resolution criteria: Either NBER declares recession OR two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth in 2025
- Market stays open until Feb 2026 to catch late NBER announcements
- Uses advance estimates, so could resolve quickly once Q1 2025 data comes out

Initial thoughts: Market is pricing in <1% chance of recession. This seems like either strong consensus or potential mispricing. Need to investigate current economic conditions, leading indicators, and expert opinions.
facts: Market prices recession probability at 0.4% Yes, 99.6% No as of current data
Other prediction markets (Polymarket, Kalshi) showing 20-40% recession probability for 2025, significantly higher than this market
Fed cut rates by 25 basis points in December 2024 to 4.25-4.50%, updated projections show 2.5% GDP growth for 2025, unemployment rising to 4.4%, inflation at 2.8% core
Fed dot plot indicates only two rate cuts planned for 2025, down from three previously projected
Fed December 2024 projections: 2.0-2.5% GDP growth in 2025, unemployment 4.2-4.5%, core PCE inflation around 2.1%
NBER typically declares recessions 4-21 months after they start - 2001 recession declared with 8-month lag, 2008 recession declared with 12-month lag
Q3 2024 GDP growth reported at ~3.0% (revised to 2.8% final), Q4 2024 forecast around 2.5-3.0% per Atlanta Fed GDPNow
signals: Major pricing discrepancy - this market at 0.4% vs other prediction markets at 20-40%, suggesting potential mispricing
Fed projections show positive GDP growth (2.5%) for 2025, which would make recession unlikely under technical definition
ISM Manufacturing PMI below 50 (around 48) in December 2024, indicating manufacturing contraction

hypotheses.thesis: No recession in 2025 - Fed is engineering soft landing with GDP growth projected at 2.0-2.5%, unemployment stable around 4.2-4.5%, and inflation moderating. Despite manufacturing weakness (ISM <50), services sector and labor market remain resilient. Fed has room to cut rates if needed.
evidence: No current quarter has negative GDP growth
counterEvidence: ISM Manufacturing PMI below 50 indicating contraction
Sahm Rule potentially near trigger levels

hypotheses.thesis: Recession in 2025 due to lagged effects of rate hikes, persistent yield curve inversion, and manufacturing contraction spreading to broader economy. Either Q1/Q2 weakness triggers two consecutive negative quarters, or deteriorating conditions prompt NBER declaration by year-end.
evidence: Yield curve longest inversion in history
NBER can declare retroactively even if GDP doesn't go negative
counterEvidence: Current GDP growth strong (2.8% Q3, 2.5-3% Q4E)
Fed can cut rates to support economy

synthesis.thesis: The market is severely underpricing recession risk at 0.4% when true probability is likely 15-25%. While the Fed projects 2-2.5% growth and current momentum is positive (2.8% Q3 2024), several factors create non-trivial recession risk: (1) Manufacturing already in contraction (ISM <50), (2) Historically long yield curve inversion typically precedes recessions, (3) NBER can declare recession retroactively even without two negative GDP quarters if broad-based weakness emerges. The massive pricing gap between this market (0.4%) and other prediction markets (20-40%) suggests either this market knows something special or is significantly mispriced.
keyRisks: Fed successfully engineers soft landing as projected - they have rate cut ammunition
Current GDP momentum (2.8% Q3) continues through 2025
Service sector strength offsets manufacturing weakness
Labor market remains resilient preventing NBER declaration
Market knows something specific we don't (insider information on Q1 2025 data)
synthesis.whatWouldFlip: I would flip to NO if: (1) Q1 2025 advance GDP comes in above 2%, confirming continued expansion, (2) ISM Manufacturing PMI rises back above 50, ending contraction, (3) Unemployment remains below 4.5% through Q2 2025, (4) Fed explicitly signals confidence by pausing rate cuts, (5) Yield curve uninverts without recession materializing. Any 2-3 of these would suggest soft landing achieved.
